The course throws a shockingly large amount of knowledge about all aspects of the private equity business at you. There is a lot of focus on the actual nuts and bolts and legal knowledge of how things go in various buyout or bankruptcy situations. If you don't have much modeling knowledge, the course will also force you to improve modeling/accounting skills.

I learned a great amount about both corporate finance and private equity space. This class enhanced my technical skills as well, in terms of modeling and accounting. I very much appreciated the fast pace of the course, making it very engaging, challenging and fun. 
I also learned many soft skills, such as negotiation and pitching.

The class is well-structured and well-taught.The professor is extremely helpful. I hope it could have met more often.

The course simply tries to cover too much. It's hard to say what should be cut, because it's all important and interesting, but a dynamic develops where because there is simply too much work, readings get skimmed and corners get cut. It would be a more effective class if there was a (still large) but manageable workload such that students could confidently commit to completing everything with a high level of detail. 

There are two solutions I see to this problem:
1) Make it a two semester course. The meat of the course is realy in learning about strategy and doing cases, but in order to do this, everyone needs to be brought up to speed on an enormous amount of terminology, accounting, and legal proceedings. The course would be more effective if there was one semester of primer on the technical aspects and then a second semester focused on applying those skills to cases. Doing it all at once was exhausting and ruled out significant success for those who hadn't already worked on the buy side or in IB. 

2) Admit students a semester early and give out substantial reading and prep work to be done before the actual course, maybe with some self tests to avaluate preparedness. This would allow the students who already know the stuff to forego a semester of prep, but also allow students without prior experience the chanec to adequately prepare and be on even footing by the time the real class started.

Strengths are numerous. The course materials are very thorough and applicable in the real world. The case studies are challenging and engaging. Professor Schmertzler conducts the classes well and points out our mistakes promptly and constructively. 
I think the course can be improved by breaking it down into two courses, because the content is so enormous that there is no way we can finish it in one course.

As much as we learned in the course, it was not structured in a way that facilitated learning, and we were not assessed in a way that reflects our understanding of the material. I felt that there was very little guidance or feedback. that being said, I learned a remarkable amount.
Fantastic course. Cant think of any weaknesses.

This class = its professor. This review is by someone who did very well in the class so it is not biased. You will probably read a bunch of other overwhelmingly positive reviews; this one provides the other perspective. The class is worth taking. However, it has structural issues that the arrogant professor will never admit and the students will never point out. The fundamental problem with the other reviews is that they reflect the culture of the class: a bunch of white, male, sycophantic investment bankers who see no wrong in their Wall Street professor.

Instructor:
	A problem off the bat with professor MS is: racialized remarks are not ok. At two points in class, he explicitly made fun of the international Chinese student for not having perfect English. Once, he joked that he wanted the assignment in English, not Chinese. Obviously, the spineless students laughed it off. At another time, he said he didnt expect the term sheet/contract written by the Chinese student to be good because he didnt know English. This creates a hostile environment for the student regardless of how casual everyone (white) thinks it is, and is just tragic in the modern finance world, where diversity is becoming the law of the land. There were also other moments when it was less explicit
	Too arrogant and disrespectful: Some professors are a bit pompous and it is funny to an extent. Here it is not funny. An investor should ask questions that make him/her change his/her mind and encourage discussions that lead students to the truth. Prof MS comes to class with an immutable, all-knowing, perfect answer. No one can ever really figure it out (and he prefers it that way) so he uses every class to brandish his superiority of knowledge. New ideas and debate of his perspective are quickly dismissed by him calling the students idiots, making fun of their speaking styles, making angry facial expressions etc. The class is antithetical to the intellectual Yale seminar style
	Poor time management: 90% of the classes were disastrously planned, which is astonishing for a class taught for so many years. In one class, we spent 1 hour (out of 1h 50m) on the pre-class quiz with 8 one-word answers. In one class that was probably the biggest waste of my time, he completely ignored the growth equity topic and answered questions about finance life/provided anecdotes. Anecdotes are great but too much class time is spent on them. Prof MS has separate meals almost every week so the anecdotes should be reserved for those. In general, Prof MS came with no plan or structure for class discussions and many important items remained unaddressed but we just moved to the next big topic
	A mouthpiece for Wall Street Oasis: Prof MS has a Goldman or bust mentality and is obsessed with brand names and image. There is some obvious validity with the perspective but it is incredibly childish, outdated, boring and suggestive of the anxieties of a college student/teenager
	Inconsistent seminar quality: Prof MS made everyone prepare extensively for 30 min presentations in the final class. Each team spoke for no more than 5 minutes. He spent the rest of the time berating us and giving us obvious advice that smart Yale College kids knew. His concerns would mostly be addressed if he let the students finish the presentation. Prof MS is not a particularly gifted presenter so his way is certainly not the (only) right way. The reality is that Prof MS uses the class as his condescension pet project and likes to listen to himself a lot more than his students and that is disrespectful to the effort students invest in the prep. Many classes reflected this. A rare few didn't
	Too much of a banker: Prof MS vibe is far more banker than investor. He cares little about the operational or industry-level value of the business and is too focused on corp fin jargon or manipulation of accounting terms. Although he is very critical of modeling monkeys he practices little what he preaches
